awd_titl_txt: Scholars Award: Technological Innovation and Networked Movements
awd_abstract_narration:
A major focus of Science and Technology Studies (STS) has been the interplay between the design of technological systems and the sociopolitical conditions they reflect and influence, with particular attention to Western democracies. This project looks at the struggle over the use and design of technologies in non-democratic contexts. Today, digital technologies are central to how pro-democracy movements build strength and how authoritarian regimes respond. The dynamic of mobilization and repression has been transformed by the use of new media and other technologies and, as this project demonstrates, is also affected by their continuous and contested reshaping. The analysis unpacks the practices of technological innovation that are not limited to Western industries, the role of IT talent in pro-democracy activism, and the impossibility of conducting sustained activist work in contemporary settings without attention to the design of technologies. The analysis has implications for a wide range of societies and political systems. The findings will be disseminated through high-impact scholarly publications and public-facing media.
 
Using in-depth case study analysis, this project considers what technologies emerge as central for mobilization and repression – and how their use and design have been reshaped, under what conditions, by whom, and with what goals and effects. This research uses qualitative, inductive, grounded theory-based analysis of chronologically organized media data to reconstruct the struggles over the use and design of critical technologies between pro-democracy mobilization and the forces that aim to repress it. The analysis will contribute to new media studies, STS, and related fields, by documenting the contested and ongoing reshaping of technologies as part of the broader struggle and by offering an in-depth case study analysis of the situated practices of the reshaping of technological use and design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary outcome of the research conducted during the funding period for this NSF Scholar Award is the in-progress book manuscript. The manuscript contributes to the discussion about various technologies’ role in networked movements under contemporary nondemocratic regimes. The usual focus of this discussion is on the effects of particular new media technologies on the processes of mobilization and repression, typically assuming that new media platforms and other technologies are developed by Western corporations and are generally stable and a given for the situations of political mobilization. Instead, this research documents the ongoing struggle over technologies and the contested reshaping of their use and design as an essential part of the broader pro-democracy struggle. Using extensive qualitative, grounded-theory analysis, this project answers the questions of what technologies emerge as critical for mobilization and repression, how the use and design of these technologies are (re)shaped and contested, by whom, when, under what conditions, and with what strategic goals and effects. This research contributes to science and technology studies, new media studies, and studies of contemporary networked social movements. It highlights the importance of understanding the ongoing technological innovation in use and design and the corresponding role of IT specialists and content creators as critical to mobilization and repression in diverse political systems. Data collection, analysis, and manuscript drafting were completed during the twelve-month funding period. Because the funding period is too brief for the traditional publication process, actual publication and dissemination of the results of this research will continue post-funding. Secondary outcomes of this research include public presentations to specialized and broader audiences and anticipated publication in disciplinary journals. Although the project did not include formal student support, it provided valuable student mentoring opportunities.
